Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Crackling noise is the intermittent, scale-invariant response of materials systems to external forces. The Earth's crust crackles through earthquakes when sheared by continental drift; paper crackles when crumpled; iron crackles (Barkhausen noise) when magnetized; nanowires crackle when bent; bones crackle before they fracture. The broad range of event sizes in each of these systems reflects emergent scale invariance, which we understand using scaling methods underpinned by renormalization-group theory. The field of crackling noise is maturing scientifically, where identification and quantification of universal scaling functions and corrections to scaling are playing a central role in future applications. With support from the Division of Materials Research, the investigators in the US/Italian Materials World Network project will develop and hone methods to find effective, powerful multivariable scaling functions to describe the effects of long-range fields on crackling noise in magnets and glassy metals, to understand crossovers between different types of emergent scale invariance, and to test basic assumptions in the field about the relation of continuous evolution models and lattice models. In each project, they propose to systematically analyze analytic, singular, and subdominant corrections to the theory, rigorously assess statistical and systematic errors, and extend the realm of applicability of these powerful theories.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Many systems, when squeezed, stretched, or twisted, emit crackling noise. The earth's crust crackles through earthquakes as the continents drift apart; bones crackle before they break, paper crackles when crumpled. While a nuisance in many practical applications, this noise can also be useful in testing and predicting failure in materials. The noise also becomes more severe the smaller the system, and can be dominant for some nanoscale systems (forming wires on integrated circuits in modern electronics, for example). Crackling noise happens when a slow force produces a series of sharp events with an enormous range of sizes. In the past two decades, the investigators have explained why crackling noise arises, using tools from statistical mechanics. In this joint international project, they will lead a team of graduate students and post-docs from the US and Italy to turn this explanation into a quantitative tool for predicting and controlling crackling noise. This interdisciplinary project will expose theoretical physics students both to state-of-the art tools in statistical mechanics and to practical materials problems in engineering fracture, nanotechnology and microelectronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rice Krispies in milk, crumpling paper, and earthquakes from the motion of tectonic plates, all exhibit crackling noise. Crackling noise is interesting and comprehensible because it is scale invariant: there are many small earthquakes and only a few large ones, but the large ones look the same as blown-up versions of the small ones. This grant supported the study of emergent scale invariance in fluid imbibition; the milk enters Rice Krispies (or coffee is absorbed into a paper towel) with a jerky, irregular front whose behavior crosses over from one scale invariant behavior to another. It studied scale invariance in glasses and granular materials, where we unified puzzling the elastic properties into an elegant theory, and studied the behavior as the materials are sheared. It developed a better understanding of scale invariance near abrupt transitions, applicable to boiling at high pressures.  It unified our methods of calculating the properties of systems with emergent scale invariance. 

This grant also supported work studying systems with simple emergent properties that are not explained by scale invariance, by studying the geometry of the high-dimensional surfaces describing the predictions and behavior of the system. Our methods can explain why the behavior of human cells depends only on a few combinations of the complicated interactions between proteins, RNA, and DNA. They can explain why complex instruments like particle accelerators depend on only a few combinations of the knobs used to tune them, and use our methods to find better ways of designing and controlling them. This grant supported work using similar methods to analyze stock prices in high dimensions, automatically predicting the sectors of our economy. Finally, this grant supported work discovering that machine learning algorithms learn to recognize images in a way very different from other kinds of physical theories and models.

This project originally was part of the Materials World Network program funding international collaboration, supporting ongoing collaborations with Stefano Zapperi, now in Milan. Zapperi has become interested in biophysical questions, and has drawn the PI into some of his investigations. This grant supported work on the growth statistics and morphology of colonies of cells and the growth of nevi (pre-cancerous spots on the skin). It explored one aspect of the development of differentiated tissues (skin, nerves, muscles, bone) from stem cells ('parent' cells which have not yet specialized into a particular tissue). Our research found that removing stem-like cells from a tissue led to a spectacular increase in the development of new stem cells, shooting above the original level. Our models may have implications on how cells keep the right number of the 'parent' stem cells regulated.

Finally, this project supported various serendipitous developments with the investigators colleagues. It supported work analyzing single-molecule experiments where DNA is split into a Y-structure, inspired by experiments in Michelle Wang's group. It supported a collaboration with Uli Wiesner and Sol Gruner developing a porous superconducter, with a regular, twisty set of tiny air tubes penetrating the structure. Finally, it supported a series of calculations of the properties of superconductors in the presence of strong magnetic fields oscillating at billions of times per second systems are needed in particle accelerators being designed at Cornell, important for high-energy particle physics, for generating X-rays for biological and materials physics experiments, and potentially for the next generation of electronic circuits running computers and cellphones.
